content.statement: vascular:lymphatic:lymph-002-anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Lymphatic that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:lymphatic:lymph-002-anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:lymphatic:lymph-002-anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:lymphatic:lymph-002-anatomy.

anatomic_structures.initial_lymphatics: Blind-ended capillaries in tissues with oak-leaf endothelium and anchoring filaments
anatomic_structures.collecting_lymphatics: Valved vessels with smooth muscle capable of intrinsic contraction (lymphangions)
anatomic_structures.lymph_nodes: Encapsulated immune organs with afferent/efferent vessels, 600-700 in the body
anatomic_structures.thoracic_duct: Main lymphatic trunk, 38-45cm long, 5mm diameter, drains 75% of body
anatomic_structures.right_lymphatic_duct: Short trunk draining right head, arm, and thorax to right venous angle
anatomic_structures.cisterna_chyli: Dilated sac at L1-L2 receiving intestinal and lumbar trunks

regional_lymphatics.lower_extremity: Superficial follow GSV, deep follow femoral vessels, drain to inguinal nodes
regional_lymphatics.upper_extremity: Superficial follow cephalic/basilic veins, drain to axillary nodes
regional_lymphatics.trunk: Drain to para-aortic, iliac, and thoracic chains
regional_lymphatics.head_neck: Drain to cervical chain eventually to jugular trunk

physiology_notes.daily_flow: 2-4 liters of lymph returned to circulation daily
physiology_notes.protein_return: 50-100g of protein returned daily (prevents tissue edema)
physiology_notes.lipid_transport: Intestinal lymphatics (lacteals) absorb dietary long-chain fats as chylomicrons

clinical_significance: Thoracic duct injury causes chylothorax (left side) or chylous ascites
Lymph node dissection disrupts drainage causing secondary lymphedema
Sentinel node mapping exploits predictable drainage patterns

definition.@value: The structural organization of the lymphatic system from initial lymphatics through collecting vessels, lymph nodes, and lymphatic trunks to the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts that return lymph to the venous circulation.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the structural components of the lymphatic system from capillaries to trunks
Identify major lymphatic trunks and their drainage territories
Understand the thoracic duct course and clinical significance
Relate anatomy to surgical considerations and iatrogenic injury
clinical_pearls: The thoracic duct drains into the LEFT subclavian vein - left-sided chylothorax suggests duct injury
Thoracic duct injury during left neck dissection occurs at the junction of internal jugular and subclavian veins
Lymphangions are functional pump units that contract 1-4 times per minute
The superficial lymphatics of the leg follow the great saphenous vein
Sentinel lymph node biopsy exploits the orderly sequential pattern of lymphatic drainage
